TO: All NAEB Members
MOM: Harry J. Skornia
DATE: March 4, I960
SUBJECT: Committees in the
Because the Committees of the NAEB — and other volunteer help — are what
have made the association strong and broadly based, I d be grateful il you d
read and react to this note (I wish I had the faculties to make it a personal
letter to each of you — please consider it as such)* For it represents our
effort to plan better committees and better use of the tremendous human re¬
sources of the NAEB in the years ahead*
This year we have made as careful and thorough an effort as possible to begin
to improve committee structure and definitions*
On January 29, I sent the chairmen of all Committees and Members of the Board
a memo which read in part:
nFor the past several years it has been obvious that, although the very foun¬
dations of the strengths of the NAEB must of necessity lie in committees —
as the most practical way of identifying and organising talents, problems and
solutions on a national basis, and frequently conducting or supervising neces¬
sary studies and advising on staff efforts, this potential has never been more
than minimally realized,
nl’m sure that there are scores, if not hundreds, of fine people, who would
be glad to help, or who are being used as square pegs in round holes,
nI feel that committees also should offer individuals the opportunities for
realizing their best talents, achieving recognition nationally for both them¬
selves and the NAEB, and providing a channel for their influence and talents
to be exerted in a broader arena than would otherwise be available,
”In the interim since my taking over as President, I have not had the time to
do this as adequately as I would like. Even though I have consulted with each
proposed chairman, with the chairman of the Board, the NAEB staff, and various
others on committee appointments, this year's committees, once again, are hav¬
ing to be appointed with less knowledge of available talent than they deserve
and need. I feel this must not occur again.”
